publicationStmt.publisher: Digital Culture Lab, Department of Information and Library Science, Luddy School of Informatics, Computing, and Engineering, Indiana University

availability.p:
Creative Commons License
The Algernon Charles Swinburne Project, edited by John A. Walsh, is freely licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License.

seriesStmt.title: The Algernon Charles Swinburne Project: A Digital Collection Devoted to the Life and Work of Victorian Poet Algernon Charles Swinburne.

bibl.title: The Poems of Algernon Charles Swinburne. Volume 1.

bibl.ref: In Memory of Walter Savage Landor
A Song in Time of Order. 1852
A Song in Time of Revolution. 1860

note.p: A dramatic poem written in 1865 by Swinburne about the tragic mythological story of the queen of Calydon, Althaea, her son, Meleager, and his love for Atalanta.
A play written by Aristophanes about escaping wartime Athens to create a utopia.
A play written in 1874 by Swinburne about Mary Stuart's lover and eventual third husband, James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell. The second in a trilogy of dramas Swinburne wrote about Mary Stuart.
A dramatic poem written by William Mason in 1759 about the British chieftain, Caractacus, who led the British resistance against the Roman invasion in the middle of the 1st century.
A book of poetry by Catullus.
A play written in 1865 by Swinburne about a French poet and supposed lover of Mary Stuart, Chastelard. The first in a trilogy of dramas Swinburne wrote about Mary Stuart.
A second play in the series, Oresteia, written by Aeschylus. The play is about the reuniting of Orestes and his sister, Electra and their revenge against their mother, Clymnestra.
A painting by Sodoma displayed in the Sienese Academy in Siena, Italy.
An ode by Samuel Taylor Coleridge
Law issued by Constantine I that proclaimed religious tolerance across the Roman empire.
A dramatic poem written in 1876 by Swinburne about the ancient king of Athens often equated with Poseidon in Greek mythology.
An ode by Samuel Taylor Coleridge.
A book about the history of France up until the 15th century.
A drama written around 1599 by Shakespeare about the English King, Henry V, before and after the Battle of Agincourt in The Hundred Years' War against the French.

bibl.title: Henry VI, parts one, two, and three

note.p: A three-part play written by William Shakespeare, loosely based on the 15th century English politics and the rise of Henry VI to the English throne.
An epic poem attributed to Homer about the last years of the Trojan War.
A drama written around 1606 by Shakespeare about the pre-Roman king, Leir of Britain.
A Elizabethan drama of unknown authorship about King Leir and his three daughters. Written before Shakespeare's King Henry V around 1605.
A book of poems written by Callimachus.
A poem by Victor Hugo.
An Elizabethan play of unknown authorship about the founding of England.
A drama written in 1820 by Lord Byron about Faliero, the Doge of Venice, and his attempted coup d'etat in 1355.
A play written in 1881 by Swinburne. The second in a trilogy of dramas Swinburne wrote about Mary Stuart.
A dramatic poem written by Matthew Arnold in 1858 about the queen of the Messiana, a city in the Peloponnese region of Greece, whose husband is murdered by their son.
A novel written in 1862 by the French author, Victor Hugo, about the stuggles of the French after Napoleon's reign.
A tragic drama written around 1603 by Shakespeare about a Moorish General in the Venetian army.
A drama written in 1820 by Percey Bysshe Shelley about Zeus' torment of Prometheus for giving man fire.
A tragic, free verse drama written in 1899 by Swinburne.
A two-part play written by Christopher Marlowe, loosely based on the 14th century central Asia emperor, Timbur.

bibl.title: The Famous History of Sir Thomas Wyatt

note.p: A play written in 1607 by John Webster and Thomas Dekkar, based on the Elizabethan English poet, Sir Thomas Wyatt.

bibl.title: The Famous Victories of King Henry the Fifth

note.p: A Elizabethan drama of unknown authorship about the life of King Henry V. Written before Shakespeare's King Henry V.
A Roman copy of a Greek sculpture of the mythological Graces that was displayed in the main hall of the Sienese Academy in Siena, Italy in the mid 19th century.
Daughter of King Oedipus of Thebes and his mother, Jocasta. In Sophocles's Antigone, she fights for a proper burial for her brother, Polyneices, who was thought to be a traitor to Thebes.
English Elizabethan poet and soldier. Wrote Astrophel and Stella.
Older brother of Moses and a prophet.
Greek god of rebirth and vegetation.
Athenian Tragic Dramatist.
Ancient Greek Sophist and epistlographer.
A Greek demi-goddess, the daughter of Aeolus and wife of Ceyx, son of Eosphorus and the king of Thessaly.
Italian dramatist.
The great god of Egyptian Thebes, sometimes identified with Zeus. And name given to the oracle of the Temple of Ammon in Siwa. The oracle was thought to be the son of Zeus.
Lover of the Greek poet Sappho.
Character appearing in the sixth tale of the forth day in Boccaccio's Decameron. She is forced to proclaim her innocence after her lover, Gabriotto, dies when she recounts to him a recent dream.
Fictional author of the fictional epigraph to Swinburne's Laus Veneris.
Goddess of love and beauty, who rose from the sea born from the severed genitals of Uranus.
Greek god of music and poetry, son of Zeus and Leto.

A character in Shakespeare's and John Fletcher's play, The Two Noble Kinsmen. He battles with Palamon to win the hand of Emilia. Though victorious, he dies when thrown from his horse after the battle and Theseus allows Palamon to marry Emilia.
Daughter of Merops of Percote, a seer, and wife of the future Trojan king, Priam.
Famous writer of old Greek Tragedy in the 5th century B.C.

birth.date: mid 1st century B.C. - early 1st century A.D.

note.p: Wife of A. Ceacina Paetus, who had be ordered to commit suicide for rebellion against Claudius and the Roman Empire. She stabbed herself in order to alleviate her husband's fear of death.
Greek goddess of child birth, virginity, and the hunt. She was thought to be the daughter of Zeus and Leto and the twin sister of Apollo.
Canaanite fertility goddess.
A demon.
Semitic goddess of fertility and love.
Daughter of Cranaus, who named the region of Attica after her early death.
The consort of Cybele whose priests were eunuchs as well as the Phrygian god of vegetation.
Eldest daughter of Zeus, who was condemned to earth when Zeus found out that she was working with Hera to secure prosperity for Hera's son, Eurystheus, over Heracles.

Balin and his brother Balan are two tragic Arthurian figures, brothers who despite their nobility end up killing one another. Their story is recounted in Malory's Morte d'Arthur, Tennyson's Idylls of the King, and Swinburne's The Tale of Balen.
French republican in the mid-nineteenth century who was sentenced to life in prison twice for trying to overthrow the monarchy.
In ancient Greece, a devotee of Bacchus.
English poet and artist.
French politician and historian. Influential in the development of socialism, especially in France.
Italian author, wrote the Decameron. Friend and correspondent of Petrarch.
English writer. Author of A Year in a Lancashire Garden (London: Macmillan, 1879).
English poet. Author of Sonnets from the Portuguese and Aurora Leigh.
English poet famous for his use of dramatic monologue.
Italian philosopher who was burned at the stake in Rome because of the perceived heresy of his philosophy.
A Roman senator, who played a leading role in the assination of Julius Caesar.
English artist and designer during the late Pre-raphelite movement.
English explorer and ethnologist. Best now for his explorations within Asia and Africa. Friend of Swinburne.
A Phonecian who became the founder of the ancient city of Thebes.
Mother of the five Cairoli brothers, Italian patriots, all of whom fought and four of whom died in the struggle for Italian unification.
Greek poet and scholar in the 3rd century B.C.
A Dominician who played a role in bringing the papacy backed to Rome (from Avignon) and establishing peace among the Italian city-states.
Roman poet.
English translator, dramatist, and poet.
Mother of Tiresias, the blind Cadmean prophet. According to the Greek poet, Callimachus, she begged Athena to restore Tiresias's vision, which lead Athena to give him foresight.
English poet, writer, and statesman. Wrote the The Canterbury Tales.

death.date: Around the beginning of the 4th century BC

note.p: Greek epic poet.
English poet and critic. One of the founders of Romanticism. Cowrote Lyrical Ballads.
Greek epic poet.
Greek poet.
Roman Emperor from 306 to 337 who is well known for converting to Christianity and issuing the Edict of Milan in 313 wich proclaimed tolerance of all religions throughout the empire.
17th-century French tragic dramatist.
Famous Roman mother and wife. Wife of Tiberius Sempronius Gracchus and mother of the Gracchi, her two sons, both statesmen and social reformers who were killed in political violence.
Thracian goddess of immodesty and debauchery, who is worshipped with orgiastic rites of song and dance.
English soldier and statesman, lord protector of the republican Commonwealth of England, Scotland, and Ireland (1653-58).

The Anatolian Earth Goddess and "Great Mother of the Gods" whose worship was characterized by ecstatic states and insensibility to pain. Her cult was based in Phyrgia and spread to Asia Minor and Greece.
Florentine poet during the Middle Ages. Wrote the Divine Comedy.
The most important Greek oracle and consultant of the growing Greek empire. Also known as the Oracle or priestess of Apollo.
Son of Zeus and Semele and Greek god of wine and ecstasy.
She was the wife of Lycus, who had been killed by Amphion and Zethus for the maltreatment of their mother, Antipone, by tying her to the horns of a bull.
Ancient Greek oracle, possibly the oldest of the oracles. She was located in the northwest part of Greece and typically would advise people on personal issues.
Illustrator. His work appeared frequently in Punch magazine.
A Thracian tribe living about Mount Pangaeüs. Known in myth for the persection of Bacchus and his followers by the Edonian King Lycurgus.
Greek Stoic philosopher and former slave.
Wife of Orpheus. She was killed when bitten by a snake and sent to the Underworld, where Orpheus entered to get her back.
Goddesses of beauty and charm and attendants of Aphrodite.
Born Pierre Roger de Beaufort. Pope from 1370 to 1378. Gregory XI was the last of the Avignon Popes.
Goddess of harmony and concord and daughter of Ares and Aphrodite. She married Cadmus and became Queen of Thebes.
German writer and poet. Lived in Paris after 1831.
Son of Zeus and Alcmene and Greek hero.
Son of Aphrodite and Hermes. He was transformed into an androgynous being due to his encounter with the naiad, Salmacis.
Germanic earth and fertility goddess.
Nymphs who live in a garden in the Arcadian Mountains on the western extreme of the Mediterranean. In the garden, they guard the tree of golden apples given by Gaia to Hera upon her marriage to Zeus.
Amazonian Queen abducted by Theseus. She was Theseus' first wife. In Greek mythology she possessed a magical girdle given to her by her father, Ares, the god of war.
Son of Theseus. He was killed when his startled horses dragged him to his death. In Greek mythology, Theseus employed the gods to kill his son because of his supposed rape of Phaedra.

birth.date: Between the 8th century and 9th century BC

death.date: Between the 8th century and 9th century BC

note.p: Greek epic poet. Attributed having written the Iliad and the Odyssey.
French writer, novelist, playwright, and poet who was idolized by Swinburne. Wrote The Hunchback of Notre Dame.
A prostitute who was occassionally the subject of Catullus' poetry.
In the story of Tristan and Iseult, she is supposed to marry King Mark of Cornwall. But in route to the king, she and Tristan accidentely consume a love potion and fall in love with one another.
Major Egyptian goddess. Embodiment of maternal power and virtue. Mother of Horus, first ruler of a united Egypt.
Son of Aedon. He was accidently killed by Aedon when in envy she tried to kill Niobe's eldest son.

death.date: Between the second and forth decade in the 1st century AD

note.p: Born to Mary and Joseph in Bethlehem. According to most Christian faiths, Jesus, the Son of God, was born of the Virgin Mary, who conceived by the power of the Holy Spirit. Jesus was a religious leader proclaiming the coming of God's kingdom and was crucified by order of the Roman prefect, Pontius Pilate, for high treason.
A military leader who led the French in several victories over the English in the Hundred Years War. She was captured in 1430 and burned at the stake for heresy.
One of the Twelve disciples of Jesus. He betrayed Jesus's location to Jewish authorities for money.
Roman Emperor from 361 to 363 and also a philosopher who purged the top-heavy state bureaucracy and attempted to revive traditional Roman religious practices instead of Christianity
English poet.
Legendary British leader who led the British defense againt the Saxon invaders in the beginning of the 6th century.
A character in Dante Aligheri's Purgatory, thought to be based upon Pia Tolomei, who was killed in 1295 on the orders of her husband.
English/Welsh essayist.
English Romantic poet. Author of Gebir. Republican.
New Testament figure, raised from the dead by Christ (John 11:1-43).

French editor and publisher, known as a publisher of many of the Paranssian poets in his three-volume collection Le Parnasse contemporain (1866, 1871, 1876). Edited Le Tombeau de Théophile Guatier (1871), in which Swinburne's work appears.
An Italian poet, writer, and philosopher.
In Roman mythology, the godess of corpses and funerals.
Roman Emperor from 308 to 324 who coauthored the Edict of Milan and was eventually executed on the orders of Constantine I.
A pseudonymn for Valumnia Cytheris, a freedwoman, actress, and mistress of Mark Antony and Cornelius Gallus, given her by Gallus in his four books of elegies.
English Elizabethan playwright and contemporary of William Shakespeare. His Tamburlaine was one of the first English plays in free verse, the form later made famous by Shakespeare.
French aristocrat, revolutionary politician, philosopher, and writer famous for his libertine sexuality and lifestyle.
One of the inner circle of followers of Jesus. She witnessed the crucifixtion and was one of the first witnesses of Jesus' resurrection.
Mother of Jesus. Known as the Virgin Mary because she was said to have conceived by the power of the Holy Spirit.

Sole surviving legitimate child of King James VI, King of Scotland. She was made queen of Scotland at six days old. She was imprisoned in Loch Leven Castle and later executed by Queen Elizabeth the First for fear she would abdicate the English crown.
Italian patriot, idolized by Swinburne.

The son of Althaea, the queen of Calydon, whose love for Atalanta led to his killing of Althaea's brothers and, in turn, his death when Althaea intentionally placed a brand on the fire that the fates had predicted would bring the end of Meleager' life.
Seventeenth-century English poet. Author of Paradise Lost and Samson Agonistes. Republican and official in Cromwell's Commonwealth.
English painter, poet, and artist. Friend of Swinburne, associated with the Pre-Raphelite movement.
Son of a sheppard, who witnessed the presence of God in a buring bush near Horeb in the Sinai region of Egypt. He was given the Ten Commandments and told to lead the Hebrews out of Egypt.

person.persName: Napoleon I, Emperor of the French

note.p: French general during the later years of the Revolution (1788-1799) and, later, the Consul and renown Emperor of France.
Roman emperor from 54-68 C.E.. Known for being the emperor during the great fire of Rome in 64 C.E..

Wife of Tantalus, the King of ancient Sipylus, who gave birth to 14 children. In Greek mythology her bragging about her fertility upset Leto, who employed her 2 children, Apollo and Artemis to kill Niobe's children.
Thebean king, who, according to Sophocles, unknowingly killed his father and marries his mother.
Son of Agamemnon and Clytemnestra. He killed his mother in revenge for her murder of Agamemnon.
He was considered the greatest musician and poet of Greek myth, who used his song most notably to save the Argonauts from the Sirens and to attempt bringing his wife back from the Underworld.
He tried to usurp the Athenian crown from Thesues, but was killed in an ambush near Gargettus.
Daughter of Helios, the sun, and wife of King Minos of Crete. A curse by Posiedon forced her to copulate with a bull and give birth to the Minotaur.

A immortal, winged horse who carried the thunder and lightening of Zeus. It was said that the Pegasus would make a spring every time it stamped its hoof on the ground. Hippocrene on Mt. Helicon was thought to be one of the Pegasean-made springs.
Early Christian ascetic and theologian.

A king of Thebes and son of Agave and Cadmus. According to Euripidies, Pentheus unknowingly imprisons a disguised Dionysus. In retribution, Dionysus has Pentheus torn apart by a group of maenads led by Pentheus's mother.
One of the twelve apostles. Originally named Simon, but given the name Peter by Jesus. Attributed with 1 & 2 Peter.
Second wife of Theseus. She killed herself because her lie about Hippolytus raping her led to his death.
Ancient Greek Lyrical poet.
King of Troezen, a city in northeastern Peloponnese. He alone understood the prophesies of Aegeus, one of the founders legendary Athens.
The seven daughters of the Titan, Atlas, who accompanied Artemis.
Wife of Brutus, who was the leader in assassination of Julius Ceasar.
Welsh squire and poet. Swinburne's roundels A Dead Friend, Past Days, and Autumn and Winter, memorialize Powell without naming him explicitly.
In Greek mythology, a god of fertility.
A Sophist, travelling teacher of higher education, particularly Rhethoric. He was a contemporary of Socrates.
Goddess of the Underworld and daughter or Zeus and Demeter in Greek mythology. Called Persephone by the Greeks and Proserpina or Proserpine by the Romans.
English poet. Sister of Dante Gabriel and William Michael Rossetti. Friend of Swinburne's.

Victorian English writer, artist, art critic and theorist, and social commentator. Famous works include Modern Painters, The Stones of Venice,, and his autobiography Praeterita. Ruskin was a passionate supporter of J.M.W. Turner, a champion of the Pre-Raphaelites, and a friend of Swinburne.
Italian politican during the Italian unification period. Friend of Giuseppe Mazzini.
A naiad who rejected the viriginal ways of the Greek goddess, Artemis, and whose attempted rape of Hermaphroditus led to their being eternally united as an androgynous being.
Ancient Greek lyric poet between the 6th and 7th centuries B.C.E. Born on the island of Lesbos.

person.persName: Semiramis, Queen, consort of Shamshi-Adad V, King of Assyria, 9th cent. B.C.

note.p: She was the Sammu-ramat, wife of Shamshi-Adad V of Assyria. In Greek myth, she conquered Bactria and founder Babylon; in Armenian legend, she conquered Armenia.
English Elizabethan playwright and poet, idolized by Swinburne and other Victorians. He wrote Hamlet.
English Romantic poet. Author of Prometheus Unbound. Republican.

One of the Knights of the Round Table. In the story of Tristan and Iseult, he is sent to bring Iseult from Ireland to wed his uncle, King Mark of Cornwall. Yet while returning to England, Tristan and Iseult accidentely consume a love potion and fall in love with one another.

An Italian Mannerist painter, who spent the majority of his life in Siena in the Tuscan region of central Italy. He is best known for his frescoes of St. Catherine of Siena in ecstacy after receiving the Eucharist in the San Domenico church. His last name, Bazzi, was often misrepresented as Razzi.
Athenian tragic playwright. Wrote Oedipus Rex.

In Greek mythology, a hybrid creature, part human, part animal. In Thebean legend, the sphinx was a threatening monster that lived in the western mountains of Thebes killing anyone who passed through its territory and couldn't answer its riddle.
Swinburne's youngest sister.
English dramatist.
English poet, who later became poet laureate of England. Wrote In Memoriam A.H.H..
Legendary king of Athens. In greek mythology, he slayed the Minotaur.
Most often referred to as a sea nymph in Greek mythology, but also sometimes referred to as a goddess or the creator of the universe.
In ancient Greece, a female devotee of Bacchus.
A legendary seer for the Cadmeans of Thebes, who had been given foresight to replace his loss of vision.
Friend of poets Byron and Shelley.
Roman goddess of love, beauty, and fertility. Associated with the Greek goddess, Aphrodite.
Roman goddess of the hearth and home.
Mother of famous Roman general, Coriolanus, who was exiled from Rome. Persuaded Coriolanus to not invade Rome.
French philosopher and writer. Major figure of the Enlightenment. Author of Candide.
English critic and poet. Friend of Swinburne's. Watts was instrumental in saving Swinburne from alcoholism. Swinburne lived with Watts in Putney from 1879 until Swinburne's death.
English Jacobean playwright and late contemporary of William Shakespeare. He wrote The Duchess of Malfi.
English writer best known for his nonfiction work, Sappho: memoir, text, selected renderings, and a literal translation.
American-born, English painter. Influenced by the Pre-Raphaelites. Painted Whistler's Mother.
An American poet and proponent of transcendentalism, the idea that the human mind can transcend the physical world on its own. Sometimes called the father of free verse.
English poet and Republican. Co-wrote Lyrical Ballads. One of the founders of the Romantic movement.

In ancient Greece, a female follower of Bacchus, traditionally associated with divine possession and frenzied rites. These were typically upper-class women, who, every other winter, go up into the Greek mountains to perform a ritual urged by Dionysus.

person.note: Early Welsh poet who mentions Arthur in his work.

note.p: Declared on September 21, 1792 with the disposing of Louis XVI. Came to an end when Napoleon declared himself emperor of France in 1804.
The national museum of France located in Paris, which opened August 10, 1793.
A school of painting in Siena, Italy that flourished between the 13th and 15th century.
One of the oldest art museums in the world, built in Florence, Italy in 1581.

A battle between the Spanish and English naval armies near Gravelines, France in the English Channel. Though the Spanish fleet only lost 4 of its 130 ships during the battle, over 50 ships were lost in retreat. The defeat marked the beginning of the end of Spanish dominance in Europe.
The Vatican council of 1870, at which the dotrine of Papal infallibility was established.
French and Papal armies numbering 9000 defeat Garibaldi's forces numbering 4000.
The largest of series of Cretan Christian uprisings against the Ottoman Empire that last from 1866-1869.

A encounter that occured on August 29, 1862 in southern Italy between the Italian government and the Italian Unificationists. The Unificationist leader, Garibaldi, was wounded and taken prisoner during the battle.
A series of battles between Parliamentarians and Royalists. The civil war resulted in the execution of King Charles I and the establishment of the Commonwealth of England.
A battle fought by the Trebbia river in northern Italy between the French and the Austrians and Russians. Both sides lost 6,000 soldiers, but the Austro-Russian army was victorious.

Supporters of Mary, Queen of Scotland and her new husband, James Hepburn, Earl of Bothwell, uprise against Queen Elizabeth I a few miles east of Ediburgh, Scotland. Mary I is captured, imprisoned in Loch Leven Castle, and later executed.

A wave of targeted assassinations and subsequent Roman Catholic mob violence against the Huguenots. The events began on the 23 August 1572, the eve of St. Bartholomew's feast day, with murders ordered by Charles IX of France. The massacres lasted several weeks, and spread throughout Paris and then to other urban centers and the country side.
One of four Athenian festivals honoring Dionysus.
An inlet of the Barents Sea, located in northwest Russia.
A region of southern Italy that was at the center of Italian republicanism during the middle of the 19th century.
A kingdom in the west central portion of Anatolia, in what is now modern-day Turkey.
A town in the Rivigo province in northern Italy.
A body of water that is part of the Mediterranean Sea and separates the Italian peninsula from the Balkan peninsula.
A river in central Italy. It was the main waterway of Rome.
The world's largest continent, which spans from the Pacific in the East to the Indiana Ocean in the south, and Artic in the north.
Consists of the western part of Eurasia that enxtends from Iceland and Russia south to Greece.
Captal of Greece. An important cultural center in ancient Greece, home of Plato's Academy, and bithplace of Socrates and Sophocles.
An ancient city in southern Boetia, a region in central Greece, that was one of the major ancient Greek settlements. It was founded by Cadmus.
Mountain in central Greece, in southwest Boeotia, near the Gulf of Corinth. The mountain was said to be sacred to the muses.
Garden outside Jerusalem on the Mount of Olives. The site where Jesus prayed after the last supper and where He was arrested by Roman soldiers.
Largest of the Greek islands. Site of the first European civilization and later part of the Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman Empire.
A region in the Peloponnesus, a penisula in sourthern Greece.
A spring in Thebes. Named for Dirce, who was killed by the two sons of Antiope for Dirce's mistreatment of their mother. They threw her body into the spring that afterwards bore her name.
Cayenne is the capital of French Guiana and a former penal coloney.
Ancient country in W central Asia Minor, now central Turkey.
A city of ancient Greece, near Mount X
A city of ancient Greece, near Mount X
A ancient kingdom in sourtheast Europe that spanned over parts of Bulgaria, Turkey, and Greece.
The field bought with the money Judas received for betraying Christ.
A region in central Italy considered to be the birthplace of the Renaissance.
Mountain range in Southern Greece, south west of Sparta.
Site outside ancient Jersusalem, where, according to the Bible, Jesus was crucified.
Mountain range in central Greece, separating Boeotia from Megaris and Attica. These mountains were said to be sacred to Dionysus and were the setting for several Greek myths.
Narrow pass linking Greece with the north, between Thessaly and Locris. The site of a famous battle in 480 BC between the Greeks and Persians.
Island off the south-west coast of Attica. It was the site, in September 480 BC, of the great naval defeat of the Persians by the Greeks.
Name given to the land located in Germany, west of the Rhine. The land was annexed by the Prussian government after the fall of the French emprire in the early 19th century.
A country in southern Europe that includes the Italian Penisula and the islands of Sicily and Sardinia. It was the birthplace of the Renaissance and center of the Roman Empire.
Large Greek deme (local community or parish) on the north-east coast of Attica. The site in 490 BC of a great Greek victory over invading Persians.
Principal river of Laconia, a region of Greece. Named for an early king of Laconia.
A river in northern Italy.
A river that runs through Attica and the Athenean plains in Greece.
The Pines, 11 Putney Hill, Putney, a district of south-west London. Swinburne lived here with his friend Theodore Watts-Dunton, from 1879 until Swinburne's in 1909.
A sea loch or bay on the west coast of Scotland.
A town in northwest Suffolk county in England.
Undercliff southwest England that stetches for five miles.
A parish and market town in Berwickshire, Scotland.
A villiage on the eastern coast of Northumberland in England.
A dependant state of England in the off the coast of Normandy that includes the island of Guernsey and various other islands in the English Channel.
A legendary city located in present day northwest Turkey. In Homer's Iliad it was the center of the Trojan War.
A comune in the province of Rome in Italy.
Country in southeast Europe and site of the first European civilization.
A city-state of ancient Mesopetamia. First appeared as a small town in the 23rd century B.C. It became the center of the Neo-Baylonian Empire in 6th century B.C.
A comune in the province of Florence in Italy that is located on a hill which overlooks the city of Florence.
A geopolitical region between Europe, Asia, and the Middle East. The area includes the Caucasus Mountains, which separate Europe from Asia.
Country located in western Europe, bordered by the Atlantic Ocean to the west, the English Channel to the north, and the Mediterranean Sea to the south.
Country in central Europe located to the north of Czech Republic and to the east of Germany.
The largest country in the world, which spans multiple continents over much of northern Eurasia.

A landlocked country in western Europe bordered by France to the west, Germany to the north, Italy to the south, and Austria to the east. During the Napoleonic Wars, Switzerland was invaded by Austria and Russia. It was in Switzerland where Giuseppe Mazzini met Garibaldi.
A country in western Europe to the east of Switzerland and north of Italy. The country was in constant war during the 19th century with France and Prussia.
Country located in southwestern Europe in the Iberian Peninsula.
A country in the southern part of the North American continent. Separated from England in the late 18th century.
The capital of the Tuscany region in Italy and an important cultural center during the Renaissance.
Capital of Italy.
Island to the north of continental Europe. Part of the United Kingdom, along with Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland.
A country in the northern part of central Europe that became an independent nation-state in 1871.
Body of the water enclosed by Europe to the North, Africa to the South, and Asia to the East. It was an important trade and travel route for Ancient civilizations.
The Greek and Roman name for the Underworld. Thought to be the only destination of the dead, unitl 5th century B.C..
Large reason in northern Israel, originally divided into Upper Galilee, Lower Galilee, and Western Galilee.
A city in ancient Syria founded by Seleucus Nicator, one of Alexander the Great's generals.
A setion of the Underworld located at the end of the Earth where the distinguished live in pleasure after death.

A mythical European river that is associated with the Po River in Northern Italy. The river into which Phaëthon fell from the sky and by which his sisters, the Heliades, wept until they were changed into poplars. The Argonauts traveled the Eridanus in their quest for the golden fleece.
One of the rivers that runs through the Underworld. The dead drink from this river to forget about their lives on Earth.
From the Anatolian Mount Ida, Zeus was said to have abducted Ganymede to Olympus.
A mountain in Phrygia, sacred to Dybele, the mother of the gods.
A river that separates the living world from the Underworld, around which it wraps nine times. Also known as the river of hate.
A star system in the constellation Taurus. The brightest star in the Pleiades open cluster.
A mountain range that stretches north to south on the east coast of the Italian peninsula.
A mountain range in central Europe that borders Spain and France and separates the Iberian peninsula and the rest of central Europe.
A hamlet to the southwest of Fiesole on the Florence border in central Italy.
A church in Siena in the Tuscan region of Italy.
One of the largest and oldest churches in Florence, Italy. Several of the Medici family are buried in the church cemetery.
A city in the Tuscany region of central Italy. It was the home of St, Catherine and the church of San Domenico.
A town of Syria, with a famous temple of Aphrodite, destroyed by Constantine.
A commune in southerneastern France that was the seat of the Papacy from 1309-1377. It became part of France in 1791.
A church located in Siena, Italy, which contains the works of Sodoma and the emtombed head and thumb of Catherine of Siena.
A range of mountains that separates the Iberian peninsula from the rest of Europe.
Ancient inland city of Cyprus, which became a center for the worship of Aphrodite.
An ancient city-kingdom in southwest Cyprus. Also known as the mythological birthplace of Aphrodite and the site of a famous sanctuary to the goddess.
A small island off the coast of Greece. According to certain myths, it is where Aphrodite emerged from the sea.
An ancient royal city in southern Cyprus known for its santuary dedicated to Aphrodite.
A region in western Italy, mostly in the province of Grosseto. It is where Pia Tolomei was killed.
The 2nd largest ocean in the world. It separates North and South American from Europe and Africa.
The world's second largest continent, which is located to the south of Europe.
Town on the edge of Mt. Parnassus in central Greece. In Ancient Greece, it was the site of the Oracle of Delphi and thought to be the center of the world.
Island in the southwestern English Channel, part of the Bailiwick of Gurnsey.
A London theatre built by William Shakespeare's playing company, the Lord Chamberlain's Men, in 1599. It was destroyed by fire in 1613.
A London playhouse in the 17th century.
A playhouse in central London during the Renaissance.
A country in northeast Africa near the Middle East. Site of the ancient Egyptian empire.
A landlocked country in northeast Africa.
An ancient city in Phocis, in central Greece.
Greek island in the northeast Aegean Sea. Birthplace of Sappho.
The largest river in France.
The capital of the Greek island of Lesbos in the Aegean Sea.
An ancient city located in northeastern Turkey.

place.note: A mountain, the site of Arthur's eleventh victory over the Saxons.

monogr.title: The Poems of Algernon Charles Swinburne

category.gloss: A form of verse Swinburne adapted from the French Rondeau. Consists of nine lines with the same number of syllables. Has the rhyme scheme: A B A B ; B A B ; A B A B. The last lines of the first and third stanzas are the refrain, which is the same as the beginning of the poem's first line.
Topic map on Arthurian legend, including legendary figures, places, and events.
A figure from the various legends and folklore of the world, including Arthurian legend.
A geographic feature, such as the Ohio River, the North Sea, or Mont Blanc.
Lindemans, Micha, ed. Encyclopedia Mythica. 17 August 2004. Encycopedia Mythica. 27 August 2004. <https://pantheon.org/>.

bibl.title: Swinburne Project Text Version Typology
bibl.author: John A. Walsh
bibl.note: Used to classify the bibliographic records for the various published versions of a given text

tagsDecl.rendition: milestone indicated by blank space approximately three lines in height"
sub line group; a subdivision of a line group, such as the octet and sextet of a sonnet, that is a logical group but is not set off typographically.
/* date cell in a chronology table */ font-style: italic;

.indent:before {content: "\A0\A0\A0\A0\A0\A0";} /* Should be implmented as .indent {text-indent: 4em;}, but a bug in Safari causes block elements to re-indent when interrupted by another block element. */>
Used in rendition of q or quote for inline quoted speech or quotations that are not marked with quotation marks.
Indicates a element such as castItem is rendered in list form.
Indicates that a block in a list (e.g., a castGroup in a CastList) is marked by a brace to the right of the list block.

revisionDesc.change: Updated XInclude links to reflect to ID scheme.

entry.def: Twisting, twisted, tortuous.tortive, a. The Oxford English Dictionary. 2nd ed. 1989. OED Online. Oxford University Press. 4 Apr. 2000 .
The working of wonders; miracle-working; magic. thaumaturgy The Oxford English Dictionary. 2nd ed. 1989. OED Online. Oxford University Press. 28 Jan 2009 .
A tomb or monument erected for one whose remains are elsewhere.
Waxed, waterproof cloth, used for wrapping dead bodies.

A church service observed during the final part of Holy Week in commemoration of the sufferings and death of Christ. The service includes the public chanting of psalms and the progressive extinguishing of all candles until only one remains burning behind or under the altar.
At or forming the top or highest point.

div.head:
To
Theodore Watts-Dunton
Dedicatory Epistle
div.p: To my best and dearest friend I dedicate the first collected edition of my poems, and to him I address what I have to say on the occasion.

You will agree with me that it is impossible for any man to undertake the task of commentary, however brief and succinct, on anything he has done or tried to do, without incurring the charge of egoism. But there are two kinds of egoism, the furtive and the frank: and the outspoken and open-hearted candour of Milton and Wordsworth, Corneille and Hugo, is not the least or the lightest of their claims to the regard as well as the respect or the reverence of their readers. Even if I were worthy to claim kinship kin-ship with the lowest or with the highest of these deathless names, I would not seek to shelter myself under the shadow of its authority. The question would still remain open on all sides. Whether it is worth while for any man to offer any remarks or for any other man to read his remarks on his own work, his own ambition, or his own attempts, he cannot of course determine. If there are great
examples of abstinence from such a doubtful enterpriseenter-prise, there are likewise great examples to the contrary. As long as the writer can succeed in evading the kindred charges and cognate risks of vanity and humility, there can be no reason why he should not undertake it. And when he has nothing to regret and nothing to recant, when he finds nothing that he could wish to cancel, to alter, or to unsay, in any page he has ever laid before his reader, he need not be seriously troubled by the inevitable consciousness that the work of his early youth is not and cannot be unnaturally unlike the work of a very young man. This would be no excuse for it, if it were in any sense bad work: if it be so, no apology would avail; and I certainly have none to offer.

It is now thirty-six years since my first volume of miscellaneous verse, lyrical and dramatic and elegiac and generally heterogeneous, had as quaint a reception and as singular a fortune as I have ever heard or read of. I do not think you will differ from my opinion that what is best in it cannot be divided from what is not so good by any other line of division than that which makes off mature from immature execution—in other words, complete from incomplete conception. For its author the most amusing and satisfying result of the clatter aroused by it was the deep diversion of collating and comparing the variously inaccurate verdicts of the scornful or mournful censors who insisted on regarding all the studies of passion or sensation attempted or achieved
in it as either confessions of positive fact or excursion excur-sion of absolute fancy. There are photographs from life in the book; and there are sketches from imagination. Some which keen-sighted criticism has dismissed with a smile as ideal or imaginary were as real and actual as they well could be: others which have been taken for obvious transcripts from memory were utterly fantastic or dramatic. If the two kinds cannot be distinguished, it is surely rather a credit than a discredit to an artist whose medium or material has more in common with a musician’s than with a sculptor’s. Friendly and kindly critics, English and foreign, have detected ignorance of the subject in poems taken straight from the life, and have protested that they could not believe me were I to swear that poems entirely or mainly fanciful were not faithful expressions or transcriptions of the writer’s actual experience and personal emotion. But I need not remind you that all I do to say about this book was said once for all in the year of its publication: I have nothing to add to my notes then taken, and I have nothing to retract from them. To parade or to disclaim experience of passion or of sorrow, of pleasure or pain, is the habit and the sign of a school which has never found a disciple among the better sort of English poets, and which I know to be no less pitifully contemptible in your opinion than in mine.

In my next work it should be superfluous to say that there is no touch of dramatic impersonation or
imaginary emotion. The writer of Songs before Sunrise, from the first line to the last, wrote simply in submissive obedience to Sir Philip Sidney’s precept — Look in thine heart, and write. The dedication of these poems, and the fact that dedication was accepted, must be sufficient evidence of this. They do not pretend and they were never intended to be merely the metrical echoes, or translations into lyric verse, of another man’s doctrine. Mazzini was no more a Pope or a Dictator than I was a parasite or a papist. Dictation and inspiration are rather different things. These poems, and others which followed or preceded them in print, were inspired by such faith as is born of devotion and reverence; not by such faith, if faith it may be called, as is synonymous with servility or compatible with prostration of an abject or wavering spirit and a submissive or dethroned intelligence. You know that I never pretended to see eye to eye with my illustrious friends and masters, Victor Hugo and Giuseppe Mazzini, in regard to the positive and passionate confidence of their sublime and purified theology. Our betters ought to know better than we: they would be the last to wish that we should pretend to their knowledge, or assume a certitude which is theirs and is not ours. But on one point we surely cannot but be at one with them: that the spirit and the letter of all other than savage and barbarous religions are irreconcilably at variance, and that prayer or homage addressed to an image of our own or of other men’s making, be that image
avowedly material or conventionally spiritual, is the affirmation of idolatry with all its attendant atrocities, and the negation of all belief, all reverence, and all love, due to the noblest object of human worship that humanity can realise or conceive. Thus much the exercise of our common reason might naturally suffice to show us: but when its evidence is confirmed and fortified by the irrefragable and invariable evidence evi-dence of history, there is no room for further dispute or fuller argument on a subject now visibly beyond reach and eternally beyond need of debate or demonstration demon-stration . I know not whether it may or may not be worth while to add that every passing word I have since thought fit to utter on any national or political question has been as wholly consistent with the principles princi-ples which I then did my best to proclaim and defend as my apostasy from the faith of all republicans in the fundamental and final principle of union, voluntary if possible and compulsory if not, would have been ludicrous in the imprudence of its inconsistency with those simple and irreversible principles. Monarchists and anarchists may be advocates of national
dissolution dissolu-tion and reactionary division; republicans cannot be. The first and last article of their creed is unity: the most grinding and crushing tyranny of a convention, a directory, or a despot, is less incompatible with republican faith than the fissiparous democracy of disunionists or communalists.

If the fortunes of my lyrical work were amusingly eccentric and accidental, the varieties of opinion
which have saluted the appearance of my plays have been, or have seemed to my humility, even more diverting and curious. I have been told by reviewers of note and position that a single one of them is worth all my lyric and otherwise
undramatic undra-matic achievements or attempts: and I have been told on equal or similar authority that, whatever I may be in any other field, as a dramatist I am demonstrably nothing. My first if not my strongest ambition was to do something worth doing, and not utterly unworthy of a young countryman of Marlowe the teacher and Webster the pupil of Shakespeare, in the line of work which those three poets had left as a possibly attainable example for ambitious Englishmen. And my first book, written while yet under academic or tutorial authority, bore evidence of that ambition in every line. I should be the last to deny that it also bore evidence of the fact that its writer had no more notion of dramatic or theatrical construction than the authors of Tamburlaine the Great , King Henry VI., and Sir Thomas Wyatt. Not much more, you may possibly say, was discernible discern-ible in Chastelard : a play also conceived and partly written by a youngster not yet emancipated from servitude to college rule. I fear that in the former volume there had been little if any promise of power to grapple with the realities and subtleties of character and motive: that whatever may be in it of promise or of merit must be sought in the language and the style of such better passages as
may perhaps be found in single and separable speeches of Catherine and Rosamond. But in Chastelard there are two figures and a sketch in which I certainly seem to see something of real and evident life. The sketch of Darnley was afterwards filled out and finished in the subsequent tragedy of Bothwell. That ambitious, conscientious, and comprehensive com-prehensive piece of work is of course less properly definable as a tragedy than by the old Shakespearen term of a chronicle history. The radical difference between tragic history and tragedy of either the classic or the romantic order, and consequently between the laws which govern the one and the principles which guide the other, you have yourself made clear and familiar to all capable students. The play of mine was not, I think, inaccurately defined as an epic drama in the French verses of dedication which were acknowledged by the greatest of all French poets in a letter from which I dare only quote one line of Olympian judgment and godlike generosity. ‘Occuper ces deux cimes, cela n’est donné qu’à vous.’ Nor will I refrain from the confession that I cannot think it an epic or a play in which any one part is sacrificed to any other, any subordinate figure mishandled or neglected or distorted dis-torted or effaced for the sake of the predominant and central person. And, though this has nothing or less than nothing to do with any question of poetic merit or demerit, of dramatic success or unsuccess, I will add that I took as much care and
pains as though I had been writing or compiling a history of the period to do loyal justice to all the historic figures which came within the scope of my dramatic or poetic design. There is not one which I have designedly altered or intentionally modified: it is of course for others to decide whether there is one which is not the living likeness of an actual or imaginable man.

The third part of this trilogy , as far as I know or remember, found favour only with the only man in England who could speak on the subject of historic drama with the authority of an expert and a master. The generally ungracious reception of Mary Stuart gave me neither surprise nor disappointment: the cordial approbation or rather the generous applause of Sir Henry Taylor gave me all and more than all the satisfaction I could ever have looked for in recompense of as much painstaking and conscientious con-scientious though interesting and enjoyable work as can ever, I should imagine, have been devoted to the completion of any comparable design. Private and personal appreciation I have always thought and often found more valuable and delightful than all possible or imaginable clamour of public praise. This preference will perhaps be supposed to influence my opinion if I avow that I think I have never written anything worthier of such reward than the closing tragedy which may or may not have deserved but which certainly received it.

My first attempt to do something original in
English which might in some degree reproduce for English readers the likeness of a Greek tragedy, with possibly something more of its true poetic life and charm than could have expected from the authors of Caractacus and Merope, was perhaps too exuberant and effusive in its dialogue, as it certainly was too irregular in the occasional license of its choral verse, to accomplish the design or achieve the success which its author should have aimed at. It may or may not be too long as a poem: it is, I fear, too long for a poem of the kind to which it belongs or aims at belonging. Poetical and mathematical truth are so different that I doubt, however unwilling I may naturally be to doubt, whether it can truthfully be said of Atalanta in Calydon that the whole is greater than any part of it. I hope it may be, and I can honestly say no more. Of Erechtheus I venture to believe with somewhat more confidence that it can. Either poem, by the natural necessity of its kind and structure, has its crowning passage or passages which cannot, however how-ever much they may lose by detachment from their context, lose as much as the crowning scene or scenes of an English or Shakespearen play, as opposed to an ÆschyleanAeschylean or Sophoclean tragedy, must lose and ought to lose by a similar separation. The two best things in these two Greek plays, the antiphonal lamentation for the dying Meleager and the choral presentation of stormy battle between the forces of land and sea, lose less by such division
from the main body of the poem than would those scenes in Bothwell which deal with the turning-point in the life of Mary Stuart on the central and conclusive day of Carberry Hill.

It might be thought pedantic or pretentious in a modern poet to divide his poems after the old Roman fashion into sections and classes: I must confess that I should like to see this method applied, were it but by way of experiment in a single edition, to the work of the leading poets of our own country and century: to see, for instance, their lyrical and elegiac works arranged and registerd apart, each kind in a class of its own, such as is usually reserved, I know not why, for sonnets only. The apparent formality of such an arrangement as would give us, for instance, the odes of Coleridge and Shelley collected into a distinct reservation or division might possibly be more than compensated to the more capable among students by the gain in ethical or spiritual symmetry and aesthetic or intellectual harmony. The ode or hymn—I need remind no probable reader that the terms are synonymous in the speech of Pindar— asserts its primacy or pre-eminence over other forms of poetry in the very name which defines or proclaims it as essentially the song; as something above all less pure and absolute kinds of song by the very nature and law of its being. The Greek form, with its regular arrangement of turn, return, and aftersong, is not to be imitated because it is Greek, but to be adopted because it is best: the very best, as a rule,
that could be imagined for lyrical expression of the thing conceived or lyrical aspiration towards the aim imagined. The rhythmic reason of its rigid but not arbitrary law lies simply and solely in the charm of its regular variations. This can be given in English as clearly and fully, if not so sweetly and subtly, as in Greek; and should, therefore, be expected and required in an English poem of the same nature and proportion. The Sapphic or Alcaic, a simple sequence of identical stanzas, could be imitated or revived in Latin by translators or disciples: the scheme of it is exquisitively adequate and sufficient for comparatively short flights of passion or emotion, ardent or contemplative and personal or patriotic; but what can be done in English could not be attempted in Latin. It seems strange to me, our language being what it is, that our literature should be no richer than it is in examples of the higher or at least the more capacious and ambitious kind of ode. Not that the full Pindaric form of threefold or triune structure need be or should be always adopted: but without an accurately corresponsive or antiphonal scheme of music even the master of masters, who is Coleridge, could not produce, even through the superb and enchanting melodies of such a poem as his Dejection, a fit and complete companion, a full and perfect rival, to such a poem as his ode on France.

The title of ode may more properly and fairly be so extended as to cover all lyrical poems in stanzas or couplets than so strained as to include a lawless
lyric of such irregular and uneven build as Coleridge only and hardly could make acceptable or admissible among more natural and lawful forms of poetry. Law, not lawlessness, is the natural condition of poetic life; but the law must itself be poetic and not pedantic, natural and not conventional. It would be a trivial precision or restriction which would refuse the title of ode to the stanzas of Milton or the heptameters hepta-meters of Aristophanes ; that glorious form of lyric verse which a critic of our own day, as you may not impossibly remember, has likened with such magnificent magni-ficent felicity of comparison to the gallop of the horses of the sun. Nor, I presume, should this title be denied to a poem written in the more modest metre—more modest as being shorter by a foot— which was chosen for those twin poems of antiphonal correspondence in subject and in sound, the Hymn to Proserpine and the Hymn of Man: the death-song of spiritual decadence and the birthsong of spiritual renascence. Perhaps, too, my first stanzas addressed to Victor Hugo may be ranked as no less of an ode than that on the insurrection in Candia: a poem which attracted, whether or not it may have deserved, the notice and commendation of Mazzini: from whom I received, on the occasion of its appearance appear-ance , a letter which was the beginning of my personal intercourse with the man whom I had always revered above all other men on earth. But for this happy accident I might not feel disposed to set much store by my first attempt at a regular ode of orthodox or
legitimate construction: I doubt whether it quite succeeded in evading the criminal risk and the capital offence of formality: at least until the change of note in the closing epode gave fuller scope and freer play of wing to the musical expression. But in my later ode on Athens, absolutely faithful as it is in form to the strictest type and the most stringent law of Pindaric hymnology, I venture to believe that there is no more sign of this infirmity than is in the less classically regulated poem on the Armada; which, though built on a new scheme, is nevertheless in its way, I think, a legitimate ode, by right of its
regularity regu-larity in general arrangement of corresponsive divisions divi-sions . By the test of these two poems I am content that my claims should be decided and my station determined as a lyric poet in the higher sense of the term; a craftsman in the most ambitious line of his art that ever aroused or ever can arouse the emulous aspiration of his kind.

Even had I ever felt the same impulse to attempt and the same ambition to achieve the enterprise of epic or narrative that I had always felt with regard to lyric or dramatic work, I could never have proposed pro-posed to myself the lowly and unambitious aim of competition with the work of so notable a
contemporary contem-porary workman in the humbler branch of that line as William Morris. No conception could have been further from my mind when I undertook to rehandle the deathless legend of Tristram than that of so modest and preposterous a trial of rivalry. My aim
was simply to present that story, not diluted and debased as it had been in our own time by other hands, but undefaced by improvement and undeformed unde-formed by transformation, as it was known to the age of Dante whenever the chronicles of romance found hearing, from Ercildoune to Florence: and not in the epic or romantic form of sustained or continuous con-tinuous narrative, but mainly through a succession of dramatic scenes or pictures with descriptive settings set-tings or backgrounds: the scenes being of the simplest sim-plest construction, duologue or monologue, without so much as the classically permissible intervention of a third or fourth person. It is only in our native northern form of narrative poetry, on the old and unrivalled model of the English ballad, that I can claim to have done any work of the kind worth reference refer-ence : unless the story of Balen should be considered as something other than a series or sequence of ballads. A more plausible objection was brought to bear against Tristram of Lyonesse than that of failure in an enterprise which I never thought of undertaking: the objection of an irreconcilable incongruity in-congruity between the incidents of the old legend and the meditations on man and nature, life and death, chance and destiny, assigned to a typical hero of chivalrous romance. And this objection might be unanswerable if the slightest attempt had been made to treat the legend as in any possible sense historical or capable of either rational or ideal association with history, such as would assimilate the name and fame
of Arthur to the name and fame of any actual and indisputable Alfred or Albert of the future. But the age when these romances actually lived and flourished side by side with the reviving legends of Thebes and Troy, not in the crude and bloodless forms of Celtic and archaic fancy but in the ampler and manlier developments of Teutonic and mediaevalmediæval imagination, was the age of Dante and Chaucer: an age in which men were only too prone to waste their time on the twin sciences of astrology and theology, to expand their energies in the jungle of pseudosophy or the morass of metaphysics. There is surely nothing more incongruous incon-gruous or anachronic in the soliloquy of Tristram after his separation from Iseult than in the lecture of Theseus after the obsequies of Arcite. Both heroes belong to the same impossible age of an imaginary world: and each has an equal right, should it so please his chronicler, to reason in the pauses of action and philosophise in the intervals of adventure adven-ture . After all, the active men of the actual age of chivalry were not all of them mere muscular machines for martial or pacific exercise of their physical functions or abilities.

You would agree, if the point were worth discussion discus-sion , that it might savour somewhat of pretension, if not of affectation, to be over particular in arrangement arrange-ment of poems according to subject than form, spirit rather than method, or motive rather than execution exe-cution : an yet there might be some excuse for the fancy or the pedantry of such a classification as
should set apart, for example, poems inspired by the influence of places, whether seen but once or familiar for years or associated with the earliest memories within cognisance or record of the mind, and poems inspired by the emotions of regard or regret for the living or the dead; above all, by the rare and profound passion of reverence and love and faith which labours and rejoices to find utterance in some tributary sacrifice of song. Mere descriptive poetry of the prepense and formal kind is exceptionally if not proverbially liable to incur and to deserve the charge of dullness: it is unnecessary to emphasise or obtrude the personal note, the presence or the emotion of a spectator, but it is necessary to make it felt and keep it perceptible if the poem is to have life in it or even right to live: felt as in Wordsworth’s work it is always, perceptible as it is always in Shelley’s. This note is more plain and positive than usual in the poem which attempts—at once a simple and so ambitious attempt—to render the contrast and the concord of night and day on Loch Torridon: it is, I think, duly sensible though implicitly subdued in four poems of the West Undercliff, born or begotten be-gotten of sunset in the bay and moonlight on the cliffs, noon or morning in a living and shining garden, afternoon or twilight on one left flowerless and forsaken. Not to you or any other poet, nor indeed to the very humblest and simplest lover of poetry, will it seem incongruous or strange, suggestive of imperfect sympathy with life or deficient inspiration
inspira-
tion from nature, that the very words of Sappho should be heard and recognised in the notes of the nightingales, the glory of the presence of dead poets imagined in the presence of the glory of the sky, the lustre of their advent and their passage felt visible as in vision on the live and limpid floorwork of the cloudless cloud-less and sunset-coloured sea. The half-brained creature crea-ture to whom books are other than living things may see with the eyes of a bat and draw with the fingers of a mole his dullard’s distinction between books and life: those who live the fuller life of a higher animal than he know that books are to poets as much part of that life as pictures are to painters or as music is to musicians, dead matter though they may be to the spiritually still-born children of dirt and dullness who find it possible and natural to live while dead in heart and brain. Marlowe and Shakespeare, Æschylus Aeschylus and Sappho, do not for us live only on the dusty shelves of libraries.

It is hardly probable that especial and familiar love of places should give any special value to verses written under the influence of their charm: no intimacy of years and no association with the past gave any colour of emotion to many other studies of English land and sea which certainly are no less faithful and possibly have no less spiritual or poetic life in them than the four to which I have just referred, whose localities lie all within the boundary of a mile or so. No contrast could be stronger than that between the majestic and exquisite glory of cliff
and crag, lawn and woodland, garden and lea, to which I have done homage though assuredly I have not done justice in these four poems—In the Bay, On the Cliffs, A Forsaken Garden, the dedication dedica-tion of The Sisters—and the dreary beauty,
inhuman in-human if not unearthly in its desolation, of the innumerable in-numerable creeks and inlets, lined and paven with sea-flowers, which make of the salt marshes a fit and funereal setting, a fatal and appropriate foreground, for the supreme desolation of the relics of Dunwich; the beautiful and awful solitude of a wilderness on which the sea has forbidden man to build or live, overtopped and bounded by the tragic and ghastly solitude of a headland on which the sea has forbidden the works of human charity and piety to survive; between the dense and sand-encumbered tides which are eating the desecrated wreck and ruin of them all away, and the matchless magic, the ineffable fascination fasci-nation of the sea whose beauties and delights, whose translucent depths of water and divers-coloured banks of submarine foliage and flowerage, but faintly reflected in the stanzas of the little ode of Off Shore, complete the charm of the scenes as faintly sketched or shadowed forth in the poems just named, or the sterner and stranger magic of the seaboard to which tribute was paid in An Autumn Vision, A Swimmer’s Dream, On the South Coast, Neap-tide: or, again, between the sterile stretches and sad limitless outlook of the shore which faces a hitherto undetermined and interminable sea, and the
joyful and fateful beauty of the seas of Bamborough and the seas about Sark and Guernsey. But if there is enough of the human or personal note to bring into touch the various poems which deal with these various impressions, there may perhaps be no less of it discernible in such as try to render the effect of inland or woodland solitude—the splendid oppression of nature at noon which found utterance of old in words of such singular and everlasting significance as panic and nympholepsy.

The retrospect across many years over the many eulogistic and elegiac poems which I have inscribed or devoted to the commemorations or the panegyric of the living or the dead has this in it of pride and pleasure, that I find little to recant and nothing to repent on reconsideration of them all. If ever a word of tributary thanksgiving for the delight and the benefit of loyal admiration evoked in the spirit of a boy or aroused in the intelligence of a man may seem to exceed the limit of demonstrable accuracy, I have no apology to offer for any such aberration from the safe path of tepid praise or conventional applause. I can truly say with Shelley that I have been fortunate in friendships: I might add if I cared, as he if he had cared might have added, that I have been no less fortunate in my enemies than in my friends; and this, though by comparison a matter of ineffable insignificance, can hardly be to any rational and right-minded man a matter of positive indifference. Rather should it be always a subject
for thankfulness and self-congratulations if a man can honestly and reasonably feel assured that his friends and foes alike have been always and at almost all points the very men he would have chosen, had choice and foresight been allowed him, at the very outset of his career in life. I should never, when a boy, have dared to dream that as a man I might possibly be admitted to the personal acquaintance of the three living gods, I do not say of my idolatry, for idolatry is a term inapplicable where the gods are real and true, but of my whole-souled and single-hearted worship: and yet, when writing of Landor, of Mazzini, and of Hugo, I write of men who have honoured me with the assurance and the evidence of their cordial and affectionate regard. However inadequate and unworthy may be my tribute to their glory when living and their memory when dead, it is that of one whose gratitude and devotion found unforgettable favour in their sight. And I must be allowed to add that the redeeming quality of entire and absolute sincerity may be claimed on behalf of every line I have written in honour of friends, acquaintances, or strangers. My tribute to Richard Burton was not more genuine in its expression than my tribute to Christina Rossetti. Two noble human creatures more utterly unlike each other it would be unspeakably unspeak-ably impossible to conceive; but it was as simply natural for one who honoured them both to do honest homage, before and after they had left us, to
the saintly and secluded poetess as to the adventurous and unsaintly hero. Wherever anything is worthy of honour and thanksgiving it is or it always should be as natural if not as delightful to give thanks and do honour to a stranger as to a friend, to a benefactor bene-factor long since dead as to a benefactor still alive. To the kindred spirits of Philip Sidney and Aurelio Saffi it was almost as equal a pleasure to offer what tribute I could bring as if Sidney also could have honoured me with his personal friendship. To Tennyson and Browning it was no less fit that I should give honour than that I should do homage to the memory of Bruno, the martyred friend of Sidney. And I can hardly remember any task that I ever took more delight in discharging than I felt in the inadequate and partial payment of a lifelong debt to the marvellous and matchless succession of poets who made the glory of our country incomparable incompar-able for ever by the work they did between the joyful date of the rout of the Armada and the woful date of the outbreak of civil war.

Charles Lamb, as I need not remind you, wrote for antiquity: nor need you be assured that when I write plays it is with a view to their being acted at the Globe, the Red Bull, or the Black Friars. And whatever may be the dramatic or other defects of Marino Faliero or Locrine, they do certainly bear the same relation to previous plays or attempts at plays on the same subjects as King Henry V. to The Famous Victories —if not as King Lear,
a poem beyond comparison with all other works of man except possibly Prometheus and Othello, to the primitive and infantile scrawl or drivel of King Leir and his three daughters. The fifth act of Marino Faliero, hopelessly impossible as it is from the point of view of modern stagecraft, could hardly have been found too untheatrical, too utterly given over to talk without action, by the audiences audi-ences which endured and applauded the magnificent monotony of Chapman’s eloquence—the fervent and inexhaustible declamation which was offered and accepted as a substitute for study of character and interest of action when his two finest plays, if plays they can be called, found favour with an incredibly intelligent and an inconceivably tolerant audience. The metrical or executive experiment attempted and carried through in Locrine would have been improper to any but a purely and wholly romantic play or poem: I do not think that the life of human character or lifelikeness of dramatic dialogue has suffered from the bondage of rhyme or has been sacrificed to the exigence of metre. The tragedy of The Sisters, however defective it may be in theatrical interest or progressive action, is the only modern English Eng-lish play I know in which realism in the reproduction of natural dialogue and accuracy in the representation of natural intercourse between men and women of gentle birth and breeding have been found or made compatible with expression in genuine if simple blank verse. It is not for me to decide whether
anything in the figures which play their parts on my imaginary through realistic stage may be worthy of sympathy, attention, or interest: but I think they talk and act as they would have done in life without with-out ever lapsing into platitude or breaking out of nature.

In Rosamund, Queen of the Lombards, I took up a subject long since mishandled by an English dramatist of all but the highest rank, and one which in later days Alfieri had commemorated in a magnificent magni-cent passage of a wholly unhistoric and somewhat unsatisfactory play. The comparatively slight deviation devia-tion from historic records in the final catastrophe or consummation of mine is not, I think, to say the least, injurious to the tragic effect or the moral interest of the story.

A writer conscious of any natural command over the musical resources of his language can hardly fail to take such pleasure in the enjoyment of this gift or instinct as the greatest writer and the greatest versifier of our age must have felt at its highest possible degree when composing a musical exercise of such incomparable scope and fullness as Les Djinns. But if he be a poet after the order of Hugo or Coleridge or Shelley, the result will be something very much more than a musical exercise; though indeed, except to such ears as should always be kept closed against poetry, there is no music in verse which has not in it sufficient fullness and ripeness of meaning, sufficient adequacy of emotion or of
thought, to abide the analysis of any other than the purblind scrutiny of prepossession or the squint-eyed inspection of malignity. There may perhaps be somewhat more depth and variety of feeling or reflection re-flection condensed into the narrow frame of the poems which compose A Century of Roundels than would be needed to fulfil the epic vacuity of a ChœrilusChoerilus or Coluthus. And the form chosen for my only narrative poem was chosen as a test of the truth of my conviction that such work could be done better on the straitest and the strictest principles of verse than on the looser and more slippery lines of mediævalmediaeval or modern improvisation improvi-sation . The impulsive and irregular verse which had been held sufficient for the stanza selected or accepted by Thornton and by Tennyson seemed capable of improvement and invigoration as a vehicle or a medium for poetic narrative. And I think it has not been found unfit to give something of dignity as well as facility to a narrative which recasts in modern English verse one of the noblest and loveliest old English legends. There is no episode in the cycle of Arthurian romance more genuinely Homeric in its sublime simplicity and its pathetic sublimity of submission to the masterdom of fate than that which I have rather reproduced than recast in The Tale of Balen : and impossible as it is to render the text or express the spirit of the Iliad in English prose or rhyme—above all, in English blank verse—it is possible, in such a metre
as was chosen and refashioned for this poem, to give some sense of the rage and rapture of battle for which Homer himself could only find fit and full expression by similitudes drawn like mine from the revels and the terrors and the glories of the sea.

It is nothing to me that what I write should find immediate or general acceptance: it is much to know that on the whole it has won for me the right to address this dedication and inscribe this edition to you.
